awd_titl_txt: Urban Clinical Residency and Induction Support for Preparing Secondary STEM Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Indianapolis will undertake "UIndy STEM3", a Noyce Track 1 (Scholarships & Stipends) project that will recruit and prepare at least 36 STEM graduates and/or STEM professionals who are committed to serve as secondary STEM teachers. To prepare highly effective STEM teachers who possess both content and pedagogical knowledge, the project will integrate coursework with classroom practice in a year-long clinical residency, during which Noyce Scholars will work under the guidance of a cooperating mentor teacher in a partnering high-need school district. This will be followed by two years of post-residency mentoring support. To enhance learning in STEM courses, Noyce Scholars will incorporate project based learning as an instructional strategy. This model will prepare Noyce Scholars to serve as teacher leaders who are able to: translate content knowledge into culturally and developmentally responsive curricula; employ a variety of strategies to encourage students' literacy, engagement, and self-efficacy; employ differentiated instruction to meet the needs of all students; assess the impact of professional practice on student achievement; use data-driven reflection to modify professional practice; and advocate for high-quality urban education.

The UIndy STEM3 Noyce Initiative will model best practices in teacher preparation through: the integration of a clinical residency experience with rigorous coursework; authentic collaborative relationships between the university and high-need local education agencies; and authentic collaboration between the faculty of the Shaheen College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Education. Coursework and clinical residency experiences will be integrated in a full-time program aligned with local education agency calendars and will result in scholars earning, within one year, a Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree along with licensure in a STEM content
area.  The impact of the clinical residency on both the Noyce Scholars and the cooperating mentor teachers (CMTs) will be evaluated. Additionally, the extent to which CMTs benefit as teacher leaders through their experience engaging Noyce Scholars and from their relationships with university faculty will be assessed. Ultimately, the findings from this project will contribute to the knowledge of effective practices in teacher education in Master of Arts in Teaching MAT programs throughout the country and the benefits of clinical residencies.

por.por_cntn:
The Urban Clinical Residency and Induction Support for Preparing Secondary STEM Teachers at the University of Indianapolis (UIndy) started April 1, 2017 and ended March 31, 2023. Working in collaboration with local urban high-need school districts, the program combined a one-year urban clinical residency with graduate coursework and two years of post-residency mentoring support to prepare highly qualified STEM professionals (hereafter referred to as scholars) to serve as highly effective secondary STEM teachers.

The objectives of the program were to produce graduates who would serve high-need schools and districts as teacher leaders who: 1) demonstrate content mastery; 2) translate content knowledge into culturally and developmentally responsive curricula; 3) employ a variety of strategies to encourage students' literacy, engagement, self-efficacy, and problem-solving, performance, and critical thinking skills; 4) employ differentiated instruction to meet the needs of all students, including students with exceptionalities; 5) facilitate effective individual and group interactions; 6) assess the impact of professional practice on student achievement; 7) use data-driven reflection to modify professional practice; and 8) advocate for high-quality urban education. These objectives, particularly in developing teachers as leaders, were met.

Weaving education theory and classroom practice together in a year-long residency was a defining principle of the program. Coursework emphasized project-based learning as a teaching methodology and included projects in: 1) equity and diversity; 2) curriculum and instruction; 3) adolescent psychology and development; 4) secondary school science and math methods and pedagogy; and 5) urban schools and schooling. Weekly clinical seminars rounded out the scholars' experience to effectively integrate residency and coursework components. After completion of the coursework and residency, the newly employed scholars received two years of university provided mentoring that included: 1) a content-area mentor who maintained regular contact with that scholar via in-person observations and/or through various technologies; and 2) participation in four Super Saturdays each year that featured workshops and critical conversations designed to help scholars successfully navigate their first two years of teaching.

The UIndy Shaheen College of Arts and Sciences and School of Education faculty collaborated extensively and met regularly to ensure the success of the program. Cooperating mentor teachers (CMTs) and clinical faculty from partner school districts also met regularly with university faculty to discuss ways to effectively support the scholars. One of the most useful items to come from those discussions was the development of a semester-long, week by week quick reference guide for scholars and CMTs describing what scholars were working on each week and the CMT's role for that week.

Dissemination of project results occurred throughout the program and included 24 presentations at state, regional, and national conferences by program faculty and/or scholars and publication of two book chapters: 1) Baker, K. M., Lee, J. S., Stickney, K. W., Sachs, D. D. (2022) A Case for Clinical Residencies in Developing Teacher Leaders in N. Bond (Ed.), The Power of Teacher Leaders: Their Roles, Influence, and Impact (2nd ed., pp. 115-130). Kappa Delta Pi and Routledge Co-Publication; and 2) Stickney, K. W.; Baker, K. M.; Sachs, D. Teach (STEM)3: A clinical residency model for preparing effective STEM teachers, in Best Practices in Chemistry Teacher Education, Boesdorfer, S. ed. ACS Books: Washington, DC 2019.

The National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program encourages talented STEM majors and professionals to become K-12 STEM teachers. As a result of the NSF Noyce grant, the UIndy Urban Clinical Residency and Induction Support for Preparing Secondary STEM Teachers program produced twenty scholars who entered the teaching profession. Ninety percent of those scholars are still teaching with several having assumed leadership roles within their departments, schools, or professional organizations.


 

 


Last Modified: 06/16/2023
Modified by: Katherine Stickney
